Inside the House leadership scramble.

                AP Photo

            By 
Anna Palmer
             and 
Jake Sherman

10/22/15 05:44 PM EDT
Texas Rep. Kevin Brady huddled with roughly 50 K Streeters Thursday afternoon on Capitol Hill to discuss his upcoming bid for the Ways and Means gavel, as a three-way race begins to take shape.
Ohio Rep. Pat Tiberi is whipping support for the gavel, and California Rep. Devin Nunes will consider a bid if Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan wins the speakership. Brady, however, is second in seniority on the committee, and he told downtowners he would jump into the race if Ryan wins the speakership, according to several sources familiar with the meeting.
Brady ran against Ryan for the chairmanship in 2014, but later took his name out of consideration.
One of the chief criticisms of Brady's candidacy is that too many Texans hold committee gavels — there are six chairmen from the Lone Star State. Brady told the lobbyists that it wasn't an issue because some of those chairmen are term-limited and would no longer lead the panels in the next Congress, according to sources familiar with the meeting. In fact, none of them are term limited until 2018.
A Brady spokeswoman did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Three-way race taking shape for Ways and Means chairman.
title: Three-way race taking shape for Ways and Means chairman.
